item.title: The bureaucracy that outlived every regime
item.description: This very idea marks the key difference between a coup and a revolution in political theory. It emerged while reflecting on the failure of the Paris Commune 150 years ago and has since reappeared throughout history whenever victorious political struggles have failed to achieve real transformation, ending instead in lost revolutions or counter-revolutions.

item.title: The China pivot for our students deserves a deeper look
item.description: "Seek knowledge even if you have to go to China"—this popular saying is fast becoming a reality for our students. A recent claim by the Chinese ambassador confirms that 20,000 Bangladeshi students are currently studying in China.

item.title: Unity is victory, division is decay

item.description: I write as Sweden's human rights ambassador and as a committed partner to Bangladesh in the shared pursuit of democracy, equality, freedom of expression, and media freedom.

item.title: What the BBC controversy tells us about Western media bias
item.description: The recent departure of BBC bosses Tim Davie and Deborah Turness is a masterclass in unspoken power dynamics. The headlines told a story of scandal and pressure. But if you listen closely, you hear the real plot twist: the story wasn’t about their journalism; it was about whom they offended..
